title: Group (mathematics)
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, a group is a <a href="set%20%28mathematics%29">set</a> equipped with a <a href="binary%20operation">binary operation</a> that is <a href="associative">associative</a>, has an <a href="identity%20element">identity element</a>, and is such that every element has an <a href="inverse%20element">inverse</a>. These three conditions, called group <a href="axiom">axiom</a>s, hold for number systems and many other mathematical structures. For example, the integers together with the addition operation form a group. The formulation of the axioms is, however, detached from the concrete nature of the group and its operation. This allows one to handle entities of very different mathematical origins in a flexible way, while retaining essential structural aspects of many <a href="mathematical%20object">mathematical object</a>s. The ubiquity of groups in numerous areas—both within and outside mathematics—makes them a central organizing principle of contemporary mathematics.
Groups arise naturally in <a href="geometry">geometry</a> for the study of <a href="symmetries">symmetries</a> and <a href="geometric%20transformation">geometric transformation</a>s: the symmetries of an object form a group, called the <a href="symmetry%20group">symmetry group</a> of the object, and the transformations of a given type form generally a group. These examples were at the origin of the concept of group (together with <a href="Galois%20group">Galois group</a>s). <a href="Lie%20group">Lie group</a>s arise as symmetry groups in geometry but appear also in the <a href="Standard%20Model">Standard Model</a> of <a href="particle%20physics">particle physics</a>. The <a href="Poincar%C3%A9%20group">Poincaré group</a> is a Lie group consisting of the symmetries of <a href="spacetime">spacetime</a> in <a href="special%20relativity">special relativity</a>. <a href="Point%20group">Point group</a>s describe <a href="Molecular%20symmetry">symmetry in molecular chemistry</a>.
The concept of a group arose from the study of <a href="polynomial%20equations">polynomial equations</a>, starting with <a href="%C3%89variste%20Galois">Évariste Galois</a> in the 1830s, who introduced the term "group" (, in French) for the symmetry group of the <a href="zero%20of%20a%20function">roots</a> of an equation, now called a <a href="Galois%20group">Galois group</a>. After contributions from other fields such as <a href="number%20theory">number theory</a> and geometry, the group notion was generalized and firmly established around 1870. Modern <a href="group%20theory">group theory</a>—an active mathematical discipline—studies groups in their own right. To explore groups, mathematicians have devised various notions to break groups into smaller, better-understandable pieces, such as <a href="subgroup">subgroup</a>s, <a href="quotient%20group">quotient group</a>s and <a href="simple%20group">simple group</a>s. In addition to their abstract properties, group theorists also study the different ways in which a group can be expressed concretely, both from a point of view of <a href="representation%20theory">representation theory</a> (that is, through the <a href="group%20representation">representations of the group</a>) and of <a href="computational%20group%20theory">computational group theory</a>. A theory has been developed for <a href="finite%20group">finite group</a>s, which culminated with the <a href="classification%20of%20finite%20simple%20groups">classification of finite simple groups</a>, completed in 2004. Since the mid-1980s, <a href="geometric%20group%20theory">geometric group theory</a>, which studies <a href="finitely%20generated%20group">finitely generated group</a>s as geometric objects, has become an active area in group theory.
Definition and illustration.
First example: the integers.
One of the more familiar groups is the set of <a href="integers">integers</a> 
formula_1
together with <a href="addition">addition</a>. For any two integers formula_2 and formula_3, the <a href="Summation">sum</a> formula_4 is also an integer; this "<a href="Closure%20%28mathematics%29">closure</a>" property says that formula_5 is a <a href="binary%20operation">binary operation</a> on formula_6. The following properties of integer addition serve as a model for the group axioms in the definition below.
The integers, together with the operation formula_5, form a mathematical object belonging to a broad class sharing similar structural aspects. To appropriately understand these structures as a collective, the following <a href="definition">definition</a> is developed.
Definition.
A group is a <a href="set%20%28mathematics%29">set</a> formula_28 together with a <a href="binary%20operation">binary operation</a> on formula_28, here denoted "formula_30", that combines any two <a href="element%20%28mathematics%29">elements</a> formula_2 and formula_3 to form an element of formula_28, denoted formula_34, such that the following three requirements, known as "group axioms", are satisfied:
Notation and terminology.
Formally, the group is the <a href="ordered%20pair">ordered pair</a> of a set and a binary operation on this set that satisfies the <a href="group%20axioms">group axioms</a>. The set is called the "underlying set" of the group, and the operation is called the "group operation" or the "group law".
A group and its underlying set are thus two different <a href="mathematical%20object">mathematical object</a>s. To avoid cumbersome notation, it is common to <a href="abuse%20of%20notation">abuse notation</a> by using the same symbol to denote both. This reflects also an informal way of thinking: that the group is the same as the set except that it has been enriched by additional structure provided by the operation.
For example, consider the set of <a href="real%20number">real number</a>s formula_57, which has the operations of addition formula_4 and multiplication formula_59. Formally, formula_57 is a set, formula_61 is a group, and formula_62 is a <a href="field%20%28mathematics%29">field</a>. But it is common to write formula_57 to denote any of these three objects.
The "additive group" of the field formula_57 is the group whose underlying set is formula_57 and whose operation is addition. The "multiplicative group" of the field formula_57 is the group formula_67 whose underlying set is the set of nonzero real numbers formula_68 and whose operation is multiplication.
More generally, one speaks of an "additive group" whenever the group operation is notated as addition; in this case, the identity is typically denoted formula_69, and the inverse of an element formula_70 is denoted formula_71. Similarly, one speaks of a "multiplicative group" whenever the group operation is notated as multiplication; in this case, the identity is typically denoted formula_72, and the inverse of an element formula_70 is denoted formula_74. In a multiplicative group, the operation symbol is usually omitted entirely, so that the operation is denoted by juxtaposition, formula_59 instead of formula_34.
The definition of a group does not require that formula_77 for all elements formula_2 and formula_3 in formula_28. If this additional condition holds, then the operation is said to be <a href="commutative">commutative</a>, and the group is called an <a href="abelian%20group">abelian group</a>. It is a common convention that for an abelian group either additive or multiplicative notation may be used, but for a nonabelian group only multiplicative notation is used.
Several other notations are commonly used for groups whose elements are not numbers. For a group whose elements are <a href="function%20%28mathematics%29">functions</a>, the operation is often <a href="function%20composition">function composition</a> formula_81; then the identity may be denoted id. In the more specific cases of <a href="geometric%20transformation">geometric transformation</a> groups, <a href="symmetry%20%28mathematics%29">symmetry</a> groups, <a href="permutation%20group">permutation group</a>s, and <a href="automorphism%20group">automorphism group</a>s, the symbol formula_82 is often omitted, as for multiplicative groups. Many other variants of notation may be encountered.
Second example: a symmetry group.
Two figures in the plane are <a href="congruence%20%28geometry%29">congruent</a> if one can be changed into the other using a combination of <a href="rotation%20%28mathematics%29">rotation</a>s, <a href="reflection%20%28mathematics%29">reflection</a>s, and <a href="translation%20%28geometry%29">translation</a>s. Any figure is congruent to itself. However, some figures are congruent to themselves in more than one way, and these extra congruences are called <a href="symmetry">symmetries</a>. A square has eight symmetries. These are:
These symmetries are <a href="function%20%28mathematics%29">functions</a>. Each sends a point in the square to the corresponding point under the symmetry. For example, formula_83 sends a point to its rotation 90° clockwise around the square's center, and formula_87 sends a point to its reflection across the square's vertical middle line. <a href="Function%20composition">Composing</a> two of these symmetries gives another symmetry. These symmetries determine a group called the <a href="dihedral%20group">dihedral group</a> of degree four, denoted formula_92. The underlying set of the group is the above set of symmetries, and the group operation is function composition. Two symmetries are combined by composing them as functions, that is, applying the first one to the square, and the second one to the result of the first application. The result of performing first formula_2 and then formula_3 is written symbolically "from right to left" as formula_95 ("apply the symmetry formula_3 after performing the symmetry formula_2"). This is the usual notation for composition of functions.
The <a href="group%20table">group table</a> lists the results of all such compositions possible. For example, rotating by 270° clockwise (formula_85) and then reflecting horizontally (formula_87) is the same as performing a reflection along the diagonal (formula_88). History.
The modern concept of an abstract group developed out of several fields of mathematics. The original motivation for group theory was the quest for solutions of <a href="polynomial%20equation">polynomial equation</a>s of degree higher than 4. The 19th-century French mathematician <a href="%C3%89variste%20Galois">Évariste Galois</a>, extending prior work of <a href="Paolo%20Ruffini">Paolo Ruffini</a> and <a href="Joseph-Louis%20Lagrange">Joseph-Louis Lagrange</a>, gave a criterion for the solvability of a particular polynomial equation in terms of the <a href="symmetry%20group">symmetry group</a> of its <a href="root%20of%20a%20function">roots</a> (solutions). The elements of such a <a href="Galois%20group">Galois group</a> correspond to certain <a href="permutation">permutation</a>s of the roots. At first, Galois's ideas were rejected by his contemporaries, and published only posthumously. More general <a href="permutation%20group">permutation group</a>s were investigated in particular by <a href="Augustin%20Louis%20Cauchy">Augustin Louis Cauchy</a>. <a href="Arthur%20Cayley">Arthur Cayley</a>'s "On the theory of groups, as depending on the symbolic equation formula_134" (1854) gives the first abstract definition of a <a href="finite%20group">finite group</a>.
Geometry was a second field in which groups were used systematically, especially symmetry groups as part of <a href="Felix%20Klein">Felix Klein</a>'s 1872 <a href="Erlangen%20program">Erlangen program</a>. After novel geometries such as <a href="hyperbolic%20geometry">hyperbolic</a> and <a href="projective%20geometry">projective geometry</a> had emerged, Klein used group theory to organize them in a more coherent way. Further advancing these ideas, <a href="Sophus%20Lie">Sophus Lie</a> founded the study of <a href="Lie%20group">Lie group</a>s in 1884.
The third field contributing to group theory was <a href="number%20theory">number theory</a>. Certain <a href="abelian%20group">abelian group</a> structures had been used implicitly in <a href="Carl%20Friedrich%20Gauss">Carl Friedrich Gauss</a>'s number-theoretical work "<a href="Disquisitiones%20Arithmeticae">Disquisitiones Arithmeticae</a>" (1798), and more explicitly by <a href="Leopold%20Kronecker">Leopold Kronecker</a>. In 1847, <a href="Ernst%20Kummer">Ernst Kummer</a> made early attempts to prove <a href="Fermat%27s%20Last%20Theorem">Fermat's Last Theorem</a> by developing <a href="class%20group">groups describing factorization</a> into <a href="prime%20number">prime number</a>s.
The convergence of these various sources into a uniform theory of groups started with <a href="Camille%20Jordan">Camille Jordan</a>'s (1870). <a href="Walther%20von%20Dyck">Walther von Dyck</a> (1882) introduced the idea of specifying a group by means of generators and relations, and was also the first to give an axiomatic definition of an "abstract group", in the terminology of the time. As of the 20th century, groups gained wide recognition by the pioneering work of <a href="Ferdinand%20Georg%20Frobenius">Ferdinand Georg Frobenius</a> and <a href="William%20Burnside">William Burnside</a>, who worked on <a href="representation%20theory">representation theory</a> of finite groups, <a href="Richard%20Brauer">Richard Brauer</a>'s <a href="modular%20representation%20theory">modular representation theory</a> and <a href="Issai%20Schur">Issai Schur</a>'s papers. The theory of Lie groups, and more generally <a href="locally%20compact%20group">locally compact group</a>s was studied by <a href="Hermann%20Weyl">Hermann Weyl</a>, <a href="%C3%89lie%20Cartan">Élie Cartan</a> and many others. Its algebraic counterpart, the theory of <a href="algebraic%20group">algebraic group</a>s, was first shaped by <a href="Claude%20Chevalley">Claude Chevalley</a> (from the late 1930s) and later by the work of <a href="Armand%20Borel">Armand Borel</a> and <a href="Jacques%20Tits">Jacques Tits</a>.
The <a href="University%20of%20Chicago">University of Chicago</a>'s 1960–61 Group Theory Year brought together group theorists such as <a href="Daniel%20Gorenstein">Daniel Gorenstein</a>, <a href="John%20G.%20Thompson">John G. Thompson</a> and <a href="Walter%20Feit">Walter Feit</a>, laying the foundation of a collaboration that, with input from numerous other mathematicians, led to the <a href="classification%20of%20finite%20simple%20groups">classification of finite simple groups</a>, with the final step taken by <a href="Michael%20Aschbacher">Aschbacher</a> and Smith in 2004. This project exceeded previous mathematical endeavours by its sheer size, in both length of proof and number of researchers. Research concerning this classification proof is ongoing. These days, group theory is still a highly active mathematical branch, impacting many other fields, as the <a href="%23Examples%20and%20applications">examples below</a> illustrate.
Elementary consequences of the group axioms.
Basic facts about all groups that can be obtained directly from the group axioms are commonly subsumed under "elementary group theory". For example, <a href="Mathematical%20induction">repeated</a> applications of the associativity axiom show that the unambiguity of

Individual axioms may be "weakened" to assert only the existence of a <a href="left%20identity">left identity</a> and <a href="left%20inverse%20element">left inverse</a>s. From these "one-sided axioms", one can prove that the left identity is also a right identity and a left inverse is also a right inverse for the same element. Since they define exactly the same structures as groups, collectively the axioms are no weaker.

Basic concepts.
When studying sets, one uses concepts such as <a href="subset">subset</a>, function, and <a href="quotient%20by%20an%20equivalence%20relation">quotient by an equivalence relation</a>.
When studying groups, one uses instead <a href="subgroup">subgroup</a>s, <a href="group%20homomorphism">homomorphism</a>s, and <a href="quotient%20group">quotient group</a>s. These are the appropriate analogues that take into account the existence of the group structure.
Group homomorphisms.
Group homomorphisms are functions that respect group structure; they may be used to relate two groups. A "homomorphism" from a group formula_170 to a group formula_171 is a function formula_172 such that

However, these additional requirements need not be included in the definition of homomorphisms, because they are already implied by the requirement of respecting the group operation.
The "identity homomorphism" of a group formula_28 is the homomorphism formula_179 that maps each element of formula_28 to itself.

An "<a href="group%20isomorphism">isomorphism</a>" is a homomorphism that has an inverse homomorphism; equivalently, it is a <a href="bijective">bijective</a> homomorphism.
Groups formula_28 and formula_190 are called "isomorphic" if there exists an isomorphism formula_172. In this case, formula_190 can be obtained from formula_28 simply by renaming its elements according to the function formula_173; then any statement true for formula_28 is true for formula_190, provided that any specific elements mentioned in the statement are also renamed.
The collection of all groups, together with the homomorphisms between them, form a <a href="category%20%28mathematics%29">category</a>, the <a href="category%20of%20groups">category of groups</a>.
Subgroups.
Informally, a "subgroup" is a group formula_190 contained within a bigger one, formula_28: it has a subset of the elements of formula_28, with the same operation. Concretely, this means that the identity element of formula_28 must be contained in formula_190, and whenever formula_204 and formula_205 are both in formula_190, then so are formula_207 and formula_208, so the elements of formula_190, equipped with the group operation on formula_28 restricted to formula_190, indeed form a group.
In the example of symmetries of a square, the identity and the rotations constitute a subgroup formula_212, highlighted in red in the group table of the example: any two rotations composed are still a rotation, and a rotation can be undone by (i.e., is inverse to) the complementary rotations 270° for 90°, 180° for 180°, and 90° for 270°. The <a href="subgroup%20test">subgroup test</a> provides a <a href="Necessary%20and%20sufficient%20conditions">necessary and sufficient condition</a> for a nonempty subset "H" of a group "G" to be a subgroup: it is sufficient to check that formula_213 for all elements formula_186 and formula_189 in formula_190. Knowing a group's <a href="lattice%20of%20subgroups">subgroups</a> is important in understanding the group as a whole.
Given any subset formula_217 of a group formula_28, the subgroup generated by formula_217 consists of products of elements of formula_217 and their inverses. It is the smallest subgroup of formula_28 containing formula_217. In the example of symmetries of a square, the subgroup generated by formula_84 and formula_86 consists of these two elements, the identity element formula_120, and the element formula_226. Again, this is a subgroup, because combining any two of these four elements or their inverses (which are, in this particular case, these same elements) yields an element of this subgroup.
Cosets.
In many situations it is desirable to consider two group elements the same if they differ by an element of a given subgroup. For example, in the symmetry group of a square, once any reflection is performed, rotations alone cannot return the square to its original position, so one can think of the reflected positions of the square as all being equivalent to each other, and as inequivalent to the unreflected positions; the rotation operations are irrelevant to the question whether a reflection has been performed. Cosets are used to formalize this insight: a subgroup formula_190 determines left and right cosets, which can be thought of as translations of formula_190 by an arbitrary group element formula_186. In symbolic terms, the "left" and "right" cosets of formula_190, containing an element formula_186, are
The left cosets of any subgroup formula_190 form a <a href="Partition%20of%20a%20set">partition</a> of formula_28; that is, the <a href="Union%20%28set%20theory%29">union</a> of all left cosets is equal to formula_28 and two left cosets are either equal or have an <a href="empty%20set">empty</a> <a href="Intersection%20%28set%20theory%29">intersection</a>. The first case formula_235 happens <a href="if%20and%20only%20if">precisely when</a> formula_236, i.e., when the two elements differ by an element of formula_190. Similar considerations apply to the right cosets of formula_190. The left cosets of formula_190 may or may not be the same as its right cosets. If they are (that is, if all formula_186 in formula_28 satisfy formula_242), then formula_190 is said to be a "<a href="normal%20subgroup">normal subgroup</a>".

Quotient groups.

This set inherits a group operation (sometimes called coset multiplication, or coset addition) from the original group formula_28: the product of two cosets formula_261 and formula_262 is formula_263 for all formula_186 and formula_189 in formula_28. Building bigger groups by smaller ones, such as formula_92 from its subgroup formula_245 and the quotient formula_272 is abstracted by a notion called <a href="semidirect%20product">semidirect product</a>.
Quotient groups and subgroups together form a way of describing every group by its "<a href="presentation%20of%20a%20group">presentation</a>": any group is the quotient of the <a href="free%20group">free group</a> over the "<a href="Generating%20set%20of%20a%20group">generators</a>" of the group, quotiented by the subgroup of "relations". The dihedral group formula_92, for example, can be generated by two elements formula_282 and formula_137 (for example, formula_284, the right rotation and formula_285 the vertical (or any other) reflection), which means that every symmetry of the square is a finite composition of these two symmetries or their inverses. Together with the relations

the group is completely described. A presentation of a group can also be used to construct the <a href="Cayley%20graph">Cayley graph</a>, a device used to graphically capture <a href="discrete%20group">discrete group</a>s.
Sub- and quotient groups are related in the following way: a subgroup formula_190 of formula_28 corresponds to an <a href="injective">injective</a> map formula_289, for which any element of the target has at most one <a href="preimage">element that maps to it</a>. The counterpart to injective maps are <a href="surjective">surjective</a> maps (every element of the target is mapped onto), such as the canonical map Interpreting subgroup and quotients in light of these homomorphisms emphasizes the structural concept inherent to these definitions. In general, homomorphisms are neither injective nor surjective. The <a href="Kernel%20%28algebra%29">kernel</a> and <a href="Image%20%28mathematics%29">image</a> of group homomorphisms and the <a href="first%20isomorphism%20theorem">first isomorphism theorem</a> address this phenomenon.
Examples and applications.
Examples and applications of groups abound. A starting point is the group formula_6 of integers with addition as group operation, introduced above. If instead of addition multiplication is considered, one obtains <a href="multiplicative%20group">multiplicative group</a>s. These groups are predecessors of important constructions in <a href="abstract%20algebra">abstract algebra</a>.
Groups are also applied in many other mathematical areas. Mathematical objects are often examined by <a href="functor">associating</a> groups to them and studying the properties of the corresponding groups. For example, <a href="Henri%20Poincar%C3%A9">Henri Poincaré</a> founded what is now called <a href="algebraic%20topology">algebraic topology</a> by introducing the <a href="fundamental%20group">fundamental group</a>. By means of this connection, <a href="Glossary%20of%20topology">topological properties</a> such as <a href="Neighbourhood%20%28mathematics%29">proximity</a> and <a href="continuous%20function">continuity</a> translate into properties of groups. For example, elements of the fundamental group are represented by loops. The second image shows some loops in a plane minus a point. The blue loop is considered <a href="null-homotopic">null-homotopic</a> (and thus irrelevant), because it can be <a href="homotopy">continuously shrunk</a> to a point. The presence of the hole prevents the orange loop from being shrunk to a point. The fundamental group of the plane with a point deleted turns out to be infinite cyclic, generated by the orange loop (or any other loop <a href="winding%20number">winding once</a> around the hole). This way, the fundamental group detects the hole.
In more recent applications, the influence has also been reversed to motivate geometric constructions by a group-theoretical background. In a similar vein, <a href="geometric%20group%20theory">geometric group theory</a> employs geometric concepts, for example in the study of <a href="hyperbolic%20group">hyperbolic group</a>s. Further branches crucially applying groups include <a href="algebraic%20geometry">algebraic geometry</a> and number theory.
In addition to the above theoretical applications, many practical applications of groups exist. <a href="Cryptography">Cryptography</a> relies on the combination of the abstract group theory approach together with <a href="algorithm">algorithm</a>ical knowledge obtained in <a href="computational%20group%20theory">computational group theory</a>, in particular when implemented for finite groups. Applications of group theory are not restricted to mathematics; sciences such as <a href="physics">physics</a>, <a href="chemistry">chemistry</a> and <a href="computer%20science">computer science</a> benefit from the concept.
Numbers.
Many number systems, such as the integers and the rationals, enjoy a naturally given group structure. In some cases, such as with the rationals, both addition and multiplication operations give rise to group structures. Such number systems are predecessors to more general algebraic structures known as <a href="ring%20%28mathematics%29">rings</a> and <a href="field%20%28mathematics%29">fields</a>. Further abstract algebraic concepts such as <a href="module%20%28mathematics%29">module</a>s, <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a>s and <a href="algebra%20over%20a%20field">algebras</a> also form groups.

Symmetry groups.
"Symmetry groups" are groups consisting of symmetries of given mathematical objects, principally geometric entities, such as the symmetry group of the square given as an introductory example above, although they also arise in algebra such as the symmetries among the roots of <a href="polynomial%20equation">polynomial equation</a>s dealt with in Galois theory (see below). Conceptually, group theory can be thought of as the study of symmetry. <a href="Symmetry%20in%20mathematics">Symmetries in mathematics</a> greatly simplify the study of <a href="geometry">geometrical</a> or <a href="analysis">analytical objects</a>. A group is said to <a href="Group%20action%20%28mathematics%29">act</a> on another mathematical object "X" if every group element can be associated to some operation on "X" and the composition of these operations follows the group law. For example, an element of the <a href="%282%2C3%2C7%29%20triangle%20group">(2,3,7) triangle group</a> acts on a triangular <a href="Tessellation">tiling</a> of the <a href="hyperbolic%20plane">hyperbolic plane</a> by permuting the triangles. By a group action, the group pattern is connected to the structure of the object being acted on.
In chemical fields, such as <a href="crystallography">crystallography</a>, <a href="space%20group">space group</a>s and <a href="point%20group">point group</a>s describe <a href="molecular%20symmetry">molecular symmetries</a> and crystal symmetries. These symmetries underlie the chemical and physical behavior of these systems, and group theory enables simplification of <a href="quantum%20mechanics">quantum mechanical</a> analysis of these properties. For example, group theory is used to show that optical transitions between certain quantum levels cannot occur simply because of the symmetry of the states involved.
Not only are groups useful to assess the implications of symmetries in molecules, but surprisingly they also predict that molecules sometimes can change symmetry. The <a href="Jahn%E2%80%93Teller%20effect">Jahn–Teller effect</a> is a distortion of a molecule of high symmetry when it adopts a particular ground state of lower symmetry from a set of possible ground states that are related to each other by the symmetry operations of the molecule.
Likewise, group theory helps predict the changes in physical properties that occur when a material undergoes a <a href="phase%20transition">phase transition</a>, for example, from a cubic to a tetrahedral crystalline form. An example is <a href="ferroelectric">ferroelectric</a> materials, where the change from a paraelectric to a ferroelectric state occurs at the <a href="Curie%20temperature">Curie temperature</a> and is related to a change from the high-symmetry paraelectric state to the lower symmetry ferroelectric state, accompanied by a so-called soft <a href="phonon">phonon</a> mode, a vibrational lattice mode that goes to zero frequency at the transition.
Such <a href="spontaneous%20symmetry%20breaking">spontaneous symmetry breaking</a> has found further application in elementary particle physics, where its occurrence is related to the appearance of <a href="Goldstone%20boson">Goldstone boson</a>s.
Finite symmetry groups such as the <a href="Mathieu%20group">Mathieu group</a>s are used in <a href="coding%20theory">coding theory</a>, which is in turn applied in <a href="forward%20error%20correction">error correction</a> of transmitted data, and in <a href="CD%20player">CD player</a>s. Another application is <a href="differential%20Galois%20theory">differential Galois theory</a>, which characterizes functions having <a href="antiderivative">antiderivative</a>s of a prescribed form, giving group-theoretic criteria for when solutions of certain <a href="differential%20equation">differential equation</a>s are well-behaved. Geometric properties that remain stable under group actions are investigated in <a href="geometric%20invariant%20theory">(geometric)</a> <a href="invariant%20theory">invariant theory</a>.
General linear group and representation theory.
<a href="Matrix%20group">Matrix group</a>s consist of <a href="Matrix%20%28mathematics%29">matrices</a> together with <a href="matrix%20multiplication">matrix multiplication</a>. The "general linear group" formula_390 consists of all <a href="invertible%20matrix">invertible</a> formula_309-by-formula_309 matrices with <a href="real%20number">real</a> entries. Its subgroups are referred to as "matrix groups" or "<a href="linear%20group">linear group</a>s". The dihedral group example mentioned above can be viewed as a (very small) matrix group. Another important matrix group is the <a href="special%20orthogonal%20group">special orthogonal group</a> formula_393. It describes all possible rotations in formula_309 dimensions. <a href="Rotation%20matrix">Rotation matrices</a> in this group are used in <a href="computer%20graphics">computer graphics</a>.
"Representation theory" is both an application of the group concept and important for a deeper understanding of groups. It studies the group by its <a href="Group%20action%20%28mathematics%29">group action</a>s on other spaces. A broad class of <a href="group%20representation">group representation</a>s are linear representations in which the group acts on a <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a>, such as the three-dimensional <a href="Euclidean%20space">Euclidean space</a> formula_395. A representation of a group formula_28 on an formula_309-<a href="dimension">dimension</a>al real vector space is simply a group homomorphism
formula_398
from the group to the general linear group. This way, the group operation, which may be abstractly given, translates to the multiplication of matrices making it accessible to explicit computations.
A group action gives further means to study the object being acted on. On the other hand, it also yields information about the group. Group representations are an organizing principle in the theory of finite groups, Lie groups, <a href="algebraic%20group">algebraic group</a>s and <a href="topological%20group">topological group</a>s, especially (locally) <a href="compact%20group">compact group</a>s.

In the quadratic formula, changing the sign (permuting the resulting two solutions) can be viewed as a (very simple) group operation. Analogous Galois groups act on the solutions of higher-degree polynomials and are closely related to the existence of formulas for their solution. Abstract properties of these groups (in particular their <a href="solvable%20group">solvability</a>) give a criterion for the ability to express the solutions of these polynomials using solely addition, multiplication, and <a href="Nth%20root">roots</a> similar to the formula above.
Modern <a href="Galois%20theory">Galois theory</a> generalizes the above type of Galois groups by shifting to <a href="field%20theory%20%28mathematics%29">field theory</a> and considering <a href="field%20extension">field extension</a>s formed as the <a href="splitting%20field">splitting field</a> of a polynomial. This theory establishes—via the <a href="fundamental%20theorem%20of%20Galois%20theory">fundamental theorem of Galois theory</a>—a precise relationship between fields and groups, underlining once again the ubiquity of groups in mathematics.
Finite groups.
A group is called "finite" if it has a <a href="finite%20set">finite number of elements</a>. The number of elements is called the <a href="order%20of%20a%20group">order</a> of the group. An important class is the "<a href="symmetric%20group">symmetric group</a>s" formula_404, the groups of <a href="permutation">permutation</a>s of formula_259 objects. For example, the <a href="dihedral%20group%20of%20order%206">symmetric group on 3 letters</a> formula_406 is the group of all possible reorderings of the objects. The three letters ABC can be reordered into ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA, forming in total 6 (<a href="factorial">factorial</a> of 3) elements. The group operation is composition of these reorderings, and the identity element is the reordering operation that leaves the order unchanged. This class is fundamental insofar as any finite group can be expressed as a subgroup of a symmetric group formula_404 for a suitable integer formula_259, according to <a href="Cayley%27s%20theorem">Cayley's theorem</a>. Parallel to the group of symmetries of the square above, formula_406 can also be interpreted as the group of symmetries of an <a href="equilateral%20triangle">equilateral triangle</a>.

Classification of finite simple groups.
Mathematicians often strive for a complete <a href="classification%20theorems">classification</a> (or list) of a mathematical notion. In the context of finite groups, this aim leads to difficult mathematics. According to Lagrange's theorem, finite groups of order formula_330, a prime number, are necessarily cyclic groups formula_436 and hence also abelian. Groups of order formula_437 can also be shown to be abelian, a statement which does not generalize to order formula_438, as the non-abelian group formula_92 of order formula_440 above shows. <a href="Computer%20algebra%20system">Computer algebra system</a>s can be used to <a href="List%20of%20small%20groups">list small groups</a>, but there is no classification of all finite groups. An intermediate step is the classification of finite simple groups. A nontrivial group is called "<a href="simple%20group">simple</a>" if its only normal subgroups are the <a href="trivial%20group">trivial group</a> and the group itself. The <a href="Jordan%E2%80%93H%C3%B6lder%20theorem">Jordan–Hölder theorem</a> exhibits finite simple groups as the building blocks for all finite groups. <a href="List%20of%20finite%20simple%20groups">Listing all finite simple groups</a> was a major achievement in contemporary group theory. 1998 <a href="Fields%20Medal">Fields Medal</a> winner Richard Borcherds succeeded in proving the <a href="monstrous%20moonshine">monstrous moonshine</a> conjectures, a surprising and deep relation between the largest finite simple <a href="sporadic%20group">sporadic group</a> (the "<a href="monster%20group">monster group</a>") and certain <a href="modular%20function">modular function</a>s, a piece of classical <a href="complex%20analysis">complex analysis</a>, and <a href="string%20theory">string theory</a>, a theory supposed to unify the description of many physical phenomena.
Groups with additional structure.
An equivalent definition of group consists of replacing the "there exist" part of the group axioms by operations whose result is the element that must exist. So, a group is a set formula_28 equipped with a <a href="binary%20operation">binary operation</a> formula_442 (the group operation), a <a href="unary%20operation">unary operation</a> formula_443 (which provides the inverse) and a <a href="nullary%20operation">nullary operation</a>, which has no operand and results in the identity element. Otherwise, the group axioms are exactly the same. This variant of the definition avoids <a href="existential%20quantifier">existential quantifier</a>s and is used in <a href="computational%20group%20theory">computing with groups</a> and for <a href="computer-aided%20proof">computer-aided proof</a>s.
This way of defining groups lends itself to generalizations such as the notion of a <a href="group%20object">group object</a>s in a <a href="category%20%28mathematics%29">category</a>. Briefly this is an object (that is, examples of another mathematical structure) which comes with transformations (called <a href="morphism">morphism</a>s) that mimic the group axioms.
Topological groups.
Some <a href="topological%20space">topological space</a>s may be endowed with a group law. In order for the group law and the topology to interweave well, the group operations must be <a href="continuous%20function">continuous function</a>s; informally, formula_444 and formula_445 must not vary wildly if formula_186 and formula_189 vary only a little. Such groups are called "topological groups," and they are the group objects in the <a href="category%20of%20topological%20spaces">category of topological spaces</a>. The most basic examples are the group of real numbers under addition and the group of nonzero real numbers under multiplication. Similar examples can be formed from any other <a href="topological%20field">topological field</a>, such as the field of complex numbers or the field of <a href="p-adic%20number">-adic numbers</a>. These examples are <a href="locally%20compact%20topological%20group">locally compact</a>, so they have <a href="Haar%20measure">Haar measure</a>s and can be studied via <a href="harmonic%20analysis">harmonic analysis</a>. Other locally compact topological groups include the group of points of an algebraic group over a <a href="local%20field">local field</a> or <a href="adele%20ring">adele ring</a>; these are basic to number theory Galois groups of infinite algebraic field extensions are equipped with the <a href="Krull%20topology">Krull topology</a>, which plays a role in <a href="Fundamental%20theorem%20of%20Galois%20theory%23Infinite%20case">infinite Galois theory</a>. A generalization used in algebraic geometry is the <a href="%C3%A9tale%20fundamental%20group">étale fundamental group</a>.
Lie groups.
A "Lie group" is a group that also has the structure of a <a href="differentiable%20manifold">differentiable manifold</a>; informally, this means that it <a href="diffeomorphism">looks locally like</a> a <a href="Euclidean%20space">Euclidean space</a> of some fixed dimension. Again, the definition requires the additional structure, here the manifold structure, to be compatible: the multiplication and inverse maps are required to be <a href="smooth%20map">smooth</a>.
A standard example is the general linear group introduced above: it is an <a href="open%20subset">open subset</a> of the space of all formula_309-by-formula_309 matrices, because it is given by the inequality

Lie groups are of fundamental importance in modern physics: <a href="Noether%27s%20theorem">Noether's theorem</a> links continuous symmetries to <a href="conserved%20quantities">conserved quantities</a>. <a href="Rotation">Rotation</a>, as well as translations in <a href="space">space</a> and <a href="time">time</a> are basic symmetries of the laws of <a href="mechanics">mechanics</a>. They can, for instance, be used to construct simple models—imposing, say, axial symmetry on a situation will typically lead to significant simplification in the equations one needs to solve to provide a physical description. Another example is the group of <a href="Lorentz%20transformation">Lorentz transformation</a>s, which relate measurements of time and velocity of two observers in motion relative to each other. They can be deduced in a purely group-theoretical way, by expressing the transformations as a rotational symmetry of <a href="Minkowski%20space">Minkowski space</a>. The latter serves—in the absence of significant <a href="gravitation">gravitation</a>—as a model of <a href="spacetime">spacetime</a> in <a href="special%20relativity">special relativity</a>. The full symmetry group of Minkowski space, i.e., including translations, is known as the <a href="Poincar%C3%A9%20group">Poincaré group</a>. By the above, it plays a pivotal role in special relativity and, by implication, for <a href="quantum%20field%20theories">quantum field theories</a>. <a href="Local%20symmetry">Symmetries that vary with location</a> are central to the modern description of physical interactions with the help of <a href="gauge%20theory">gauge theory</a>. An important example of a gauge theory is the <a href="Standard%20Model">Standard Model</a>, which describes three of the four known <a href="fundamental%20force">fundamental force</a>s and classifies all known <a href="elementary%20particle">elementary particle</a>s.
Generalizations.
In <a href="abstract%20algebra">abstract algebra</a>, more general structures are defined by relaxing some of the axioms defining a group. For example, if the requirement that every element has an inverse is eliminated, the resulting algebraic structure is called a <a href="monoid">monoid</a>. The <a href="natural%20number">natural number</a>s formula_454 (including zero) under addition form a monoid, as do the nonzero integers under multiplication formula_455, see above. There is a general method to formally add inverses to elements to any (abelian) monoid, much the same way as formula_456 is derived from formula_455, known as the <a href="Grothendieck%20group">Grothendieck group</a>.
<a href="Groupoid">Groupoid</a>s are similar to groups except that the composition formula_34 need not be defined for all formula_2 and formula_3. They arise in the study of more complicated forms of symmetry, often in <a href="topology">topological</a> and <a href="mathematical%20analysis">analytical</a> structures, such as the <a href="fundamental%20groupoid">fundamental groupoid</a> or <a href="stack%20%28mathematics%29">stacks</a>. Finally, it is possible to generalize any of these concepts by replacing the binary operation with an arbitrary <a href="arity">-ary</a> one (i.e., an operation taking arguments). With the proper generalization of the group axioms this gives rise to an <a href="n-ary%20group">-ary group</a>. The table gives a list of several structures generalizing groups.
